This book was suggested and I therefore grabbed it from the library when I saw it available. It's kind of amazing that he's couched a book on decision making using statistics in the context of fast and slow thinking. The more into statistics you are the easier this book will be to absorb.System 1 - Fast - This might be what one refers to you nearly unconscious judgements. This will attempt to process, answer, and understand any question choice or otherwise as quickly as possible. System 2 - Slow - This requires more cognitive horse power. It must be activated on purpose. You get tired if you over use this. Then there is this concept of "Flow"P. 41 "Riding a motorcycle at 150 miles an hour and playing a competitive game of chess are certainly effortful. IN a state of flow, howevere, maintainig focused attention on these absorbing activities requires no exertion of self-control, thereby freeing resources to be directed to the task at ahand. The mind is a pattern maker and will make things that are not related related. This was discovered by Hume. in 1945 (p. 76). He gives the example that if you animate lights such that one is still and the other is moving, but when the still one is touched by the moving the two switch and the still one continues in the same path, then the mind will attribute cause to the moving light. The point is you know that the lights are animated and the real cause is the animator. You're mind however, will represent that light one caused light 2 to move. Fascinating.Chapter 9 drives home the point that it is uncomfortable to be stumped and need to use System 2. It more or less goes through all the cognitive biases we have just so we don't have eto use System 2.I like this end point of Chapter 16. He attempts to drive home how hard headed most humans are. Even if we know the statistical answer we will not truly integrate that into decisions made. P. 174. People who are taught surprising statistical facts about human behavior may be impressed to the point of telling their friends what they have heard, but this does not mean that their world has actually changed. The chapter gives the example of how someone having a stroke does not elicit a bunch of people willing to help, because in actuality most will not get involved if they think someone else might take care of it. I like it because if you consider such biases in the discrimination issues of today, it really points out something fascinating. I'll try to think more on that when i have time. Chapter 22 is interesting in that he attempts to address the issue of expert intuition. In some ways this speaks directly to the book Blink. It would be interesting to have them face off. First, we define expert as someone who has literally seen every variation and understands it, a la master chess player. They are not intuiting. They are exercising the skill. But then then the question comes in whether they know what they don't know. Hard to say. But I do like the idea that expert is a host of skills that are complementary together. p.241 - "Expertise is not a single skill; it is a collection of skills, and the same professional may be highly expert in some of the tasks in her domain while remaining a novice in others." How...P. 417 - "recognize the signs that you are in a cognitive minefield, slow down, and ask for reinforcement from System 2."I also wonder if women and minorities are socialized in the work place to be better at this. Not the point of this guy's book though, but fascinating nonetheless.Point of view is everything in this book. He goes through more detail about each of the biases illustrated in the field of decision making. It's a worthwhile read. Context is everything. In this book, the idea of regression is that it is correct, but misinterpretted (a flawed understanding of regression to the mean). I speak specifically about Appendix A, p. 424. He's right. Inference is often a problem. But I typically use the same think to describe the idea that the data is misunderstood, so inference is always wrong. I think Kanneman is game on this, but it's outside the scope of the book.Learned a lot, not the least of which, is how to present quite technical stats in a way that might make you read about it.

What you see is all there is.Kahneman talks about the forty years he has spent studying how humans make decisions, and the two main ways we make decisions—system 1 (intuition) and system 2 (slow, methodical)—and how we are easily deceived in any number of ways.While this was fascinating look at decision-making, this nearly 500-page tome boils down to one (well, two, if you set aside the oft-repeated mantra at the top of this review) take-away: if you are offered to participate in a psychological study, always decline.Perhaps this wasn't the take-away Kahneman intended, but it was certainly what I got from this, along with the thought that this could have benefited with a 200-page trim because there was a lot of material that felt repeated or over-explained.More seriously, I can see why this had been on the Commandant's Reading List for the past number of years, because it offers ways to think through decisions and avoiding making logical fallacies that ultimately will end in disaster or severe misunderstanding (oh how many majors I wish had actually read this before asking me to do stupid shit).Both gut instinct and slower thinking are discussed, along with their pros, cons, how these two systems can be tricked/influenced, and how to beat the system (basically, always double-check your work if you had time). Also: when it comes to many luck-based scenarios, the "experts" are often only slightly more efficient at guessing than the average layperson.It definitely left some interesting food for thought.

In the highly anticipated Thinking, Fast and Slow, Kahneman takes us on a groundbreaking tour of the mind and explains the two systems that drive the way we think. System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional; System 2 is slower, more deliberative, and more logical. Kahneman exposes the extraordinary capabilities—and also the faults and biases—of fast thinking, and reveals the pervasive influence of intuitive impressions on our thoughts and behavior. The impact of loss aversion and overconfidence on corporate strategies, the difficulties of predicting what will make us happy in the future, the challenges of properly framing risks at work and at home, the profound effect of cognitive biases on everything from playing the stock market to planning the next vacation—each of these can be understood only by knowing how the two systems work together to shape our judgments and decisions.Engaging the reader in a lively conversation about how we think, Kahneman reveals where we can and cannot trust our intuitions and how we can tap into the benefits of slow thinking. He offers practical and enlightening insights into how choices are made in both our business and our personal lives—and how we can use different techniques to guard against the mental glitches that often get us into trouble. Thinking, Fast and Slow will transform the way you think about thinking.

Having heard about this book for several years I was quite excited to finally start it. However, found myself quickly bored. Not to say that the book is bad or uninteresting but rather the majority of the concepts in the book are things I've learned in business/psychology classes. That being said, this book is a nice tidy summary of a lot of these ideas (how bias work, how humans are bad at stats, how our thinking can be influenced).I did go ahead and read the whole book in search of the nuggets of new info and here are some of the things I found and really liked:* Willpower is like a muscle that you build up. When you're mentally tired it's much easier to give in. And people who are cognitively busy are more likely to make selfish choices.* Money primes individualism* Being exposed to phrases/names a lot leads us to believe them* The font size/color influence how much we believe text* It's hard for us to accept that a lot of life is random (as opposed to skill)* Regression to the mean - a really powerful concept of how people who do above their average will likely regress to their average next time around. People who are below their average will likely do better next time around.* Narrative fallacy - We love stories and tend to believe them as we draw causal inferences* People will pay a premium to transfer risk to the rich (insurance policies)It should be noted, that this whole book was about the author's experiments and not all of them have successfully been reproduced. The Undoing Project is a book I have yet to read that rebutts a lot of the ideas put forth in this book.

This was a really interesting book. Thinking Fast and Slow is the culmination of years of Daniel Kahneman’s research into the nature of human decision making, how our minds process the world around us, and basically how people think. From the very start the reader must realize how difficult of a subject this is to explore and understand, let alone explain. Simply by being human, any researcher working on this has to keep in mind that he is prey to the very biases he is working to uncover.This book was organized and written very well. Kahneman divides the human mind into two systems from the very beginning, giving these systems traits and tendencies to help us relate to them in ourselves. System 1 is the fast and intuitive thinking, or (if I may generalize here) our subconscious thoughts; our automatic reactions, feelings and impressions. System 2 is our rational system; the one that is often more accurate, but takes up much more energy to use. Most of us can see those two “systems” within ourselves, and that makes the book easy to follow. He often brings up points that seem arbitrary only to have them neatly tied together to create a larger concept a chapter or two later.I feel like this book was created for those who tend to be of a less scientific mind. He uses examples of experiments very often in the book that seem on the surface to prove his point, but I often wondered about the details of the experiments, which were never included. Now don’t get me wrong; I know nothing about Kahneman’s career and have no reason to think he does not do his research as scientifically as possible; that information just isn’t included in the book. This is an overall explanation of what his research has led him to conclude; if you’re looking for details and numbers and results so you can reach your own conclusion, you won’t find it here. For example:He wrote about an experiment where subjects heard various groups of words, then had to walk down a hallway to another room to do the second part of the experiment. The actual experiment was how long it took them to walk down the hall. Some people were given words that related to older people, disabilities, and generally being slow while other people were given words that related to young people, fitness, and generally being fast. People who were given the “slow words” took a significantly longer amount of time to walk the distance of the hall than those given the “fast words.” That’s really all he tells the reader because that is all he needs to make his point. And reading that, it is very easy to jump to the conclusion “wow, just hearing words can change our actions” because it’s interesting. He doesn’t answer questions like: Could the words have evoked different themes in different people’s minds? Was a background of the subjects taken to determine their general mood? Were the fast words speeding people up or the slow words slowing people down? How do you know this doesn’t only work with certain themes? Etc.My point is, take Thinking Fast and Slow with a grain of salt. The book is fun to read in the way that personality tests are fun; it’s always neat to learn more about ourselves, and it fulfills that somewhat narcissistic need in the reader. But that’s system 1 thinking; if you go into this wanting proof, you won’t get it. This is a subject very difficult to study objectively, and while I’m sure he did the job as well as possible, you can’t know that by reading his book because he does not give details, he gives his conclusions. And who can blame him? You don’t sell a book by filling it with numbers, you sell it by making it easy to understand – and when you get into such cutting edge research, there just isn’t a way to make it widely accessible and include all the nitty gritty details.I do believe this book is a very important stepping stone. Kahneman’s research is just one step toward understanding the human mind. I think many of the experiments he talks about are not enough to draw conclusions, although he does the best that he can. Scientists will continue the same path of research he has taken for centuries to come, and his ideas will be expanded on, accepted or thrown out as we learn more. This isn’t absolute truth. But if you are interested in where we stand on understanding the human mind and what theories are out there, then this book will be invaluable to you.I do not in any way think reading it is a waste of time since the ideas will most certainly change. Throughout the book he points out many of the common illusions that people fall prey to because of certain biases in our minds, and even if he doesn’t have the processes behind them exactly right (who can really know if he does or not?), that doesn’t mean the illusions aren’t real. Everyone can benefit from reading this book simply by being made aware of these pitfalls and therefore being able to avoid them in the future.So, what do I think? He went a little light on the explanations, and I wish he had provided more of the scientific details about his work. However, I understand that the book is already lengthy and so he may not have had much choice. I do absolutely recommend this book for any non-fiction readers interested in psychology or in improving their own thought processes.

Why I started reading it: This is one those books that you can see on the shelves of youtubers, in the posts of bookstagramers and the ‘to read’ lists of most your friends.What I liked about it: The idea of explaining in rather scientific terms why we are not as rational as we think. Overall I really enjoyed this book. Kahneman is an engaging writer and brings in a wealth of information to construct a compelling narrative. I'd been aware of a lot of this literature and the overall framework beforehand, but I still learned a lot in terms of specifics and got a much better sense of the details of the system 1/system 2 model and how broadly applicable it is. If you want a glimpse of what kind of understanding psychology can offer of how we reason and evaluate, I definitely recommend this one.I had some minor nits throughout and disagreed with a few of his interpretations, but the significant detractor was the framing Kahneman chose for the book. He made some choices seemingly to promote his goal of influencing water cooler conversation (which by itself seemed strange to me) that I think weakened chances for understanding. The biggest one was the discussion of the separate categories of thought processes as separate systems with their own agency and personalities. Kahneman acknowledges this as a fiction explicitly, but that didn't seem to mitigate the confusion that I think might result. I do think there's a true and useful categorization underneath the system 1/system 2 distinction, but treating them as completely distinct and partially at odds obfuscates the deeply intertwined and inseparable nature of the processes. One particular recurrent issue that resulted from this was identifying system 2 with the self and then concluding (at several different points) things along the lines of "you don't really know/decide/etc. most things, that's sneaky old System 1". And ascribing judgmental personality traits to the systems (e.g. "system 2 is lazy" instead of "effortful thinking is costly") may help the reader from an intuitive impression of them, but with a strong bias toward oversimplification and negative evaluation.More minorly, Kahneman also usually leaves out details like how strong the effects noted are, what proportion of the subjects were affected, etc. seemingly out of a desire to craft a coherent picture that applies wholly to the reader. One of the times where he does include some of this information this gets particularly ridiculous: In one paragraph on page 171 he mentions that "only four of the fifteen participants [in the "helping experiment"] responded immediately to the appeal for help," and in the next says "even normal, decent people do not rush to help when they expect others to take on the unpleasantness of dealing with a seizure. And that means you, too.". 4/15 is pretty bad given the issue at hand, but if that generalizes it emphatically doesn't mean "you" for more than 1 in 4 of the readers! Many of the errors he mentioned I could easily identify in myself, some of them I have evidence for thinking they don't apply as strongly as he claims (e.g. actually having been in a few diffusion of responsibility type scenarios and taking action), and for the rest I simply have no way to judge likelihood without diving into the references. I think adding in these details would have gone a long way to forming a more accurate understanding in the reader, but I have an uncharitable suspicion that it would also have significantly weakened some of the cases he was making.All that being said, I really did enjoy this book and by the end couldn't put it down. Kahneman clearly knows his stuff and I'm much better informed having read it. I've already taken steps to try to incorporate some of the lessons into my thinking and decision making, and definitely plan to seek out more in this domain.

I am familiar with Daniel Kahneman's work through many of his essays and articles in various magazines in the past. I had always found them thought-provoking, interesting and challenging established notions. That is why I was excited to read this book on Behavioral psychology by him. However, this book lived up to my expectations only partially. One reason is that the author's contention that 'our intuitive preferences are more influential than rational choice' gets well established fairly early in the book through the many experiments that he describes. Consequently, I felt a sense of repetition in the latter half of the book and gradually felt that the book lost steam completely towards the closing sections.To put it simply, the book says that there are two systems which drive the way we think and make choices. The author calls them System 1 and System 2. System 1 is intuitive, quick and influenced by emotion. System 2 is slower, rational, logical and reflective. The author's research says that System 1 is more influential than what our experience tells us and it is the subliminal determinant of the many choices and judgments that we make. This is contrary to our general belief that we are very rational in our decision-making. The many example experiments that the book outlines show us that we must really be a lot more watchful in the assurance with which we trust our decisions as rooted in rationality. To me, this is the biggest lesson from the book.A few other points of interest from the book are:1. Luck plays a large role in every story of success. The author illustrates it with the telling contemporary example of the founders of Google willing to sell their company for less than $1 million but the buyer thought that the price was too high!2. High intelligence does not make people immune to biases3. Rationality should be distinguished from intelligence.4. While talking about the consequences of Priming, the author points to a conclusion that may be an indictment of capitalist society. He says that living in a culture that surrounds us with constant reminders of money may shape our behavior and attitudes in ways that we do not know about and of which we may not be proud.5. On the subject of Intuition vs Formulas, the author quotes a memorable formula of researcher Robyn Dawes:Marital Stability = frequency of lovemaking - frequency of quarrels!6. In the final section of the book, titled 'Two Selves', the author dabbles into the question of human happiness. Two statements caught my attention.a. The easiest way to increase happiness is to control your use of time. Can you find more time to do the things you enjoy doing?b. There is low correlation between individuals' circumstances and their satisfaction with life. The reason is that both experienced happiness and life satisfaction are largely determined by the genetics of temperament.In this context, I wondered whether the author is aware of Friedrich Nietzsche's contention that animals are happy because they lack a capacity for past memories. Perhaps the author's term 'genetics of temperament' include a capacity to forget the past and move on with life.I found it educational and interesting in parts but somewhat disappointing overall, given my initial expectations from the author.

In 1979, Kahneman with his longtime collaborator, Late Amos Tversky published their groundbreaking academic paper, “Prospect Theory” (which was further updated in 1992). It was a buzz in the academic world. Kahneman who later went on to receive Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 2002 is the first psychologist to earn the prize in that category. Kahneman sequenced into a book hundreds of research papers spanning over 30 years on decision making he wrote with his intellectual friend and collaborator, Tversky. Thinking Fast and Slow is his seminal work on the topic of decision making and cognitive bias.Thinking Fast and Slow is a dense, technical but rewarding read. The book exhaustively discussed biases and fallacies people are prone to make. He talks about the halo effect, affection bias, and confirmation biases. The crux of the book is on cognitive biases, yeah.Humans are said to be “rational beings.” That we are capable of making rational and logical choices. But Kahneman argues it is not always so. “Humans beings,” he insists, “are prone to make illogical choices. We rely so much on statistics, numbers, or information. We are quick at even saying “numbers don’t lie.’ Because we think along those lines, when we are fed with information about a particular issue, we start to feel that it is true or even concludes it has a higher likelihood of reoccurrence. We also make an intuitive judgment based on the information that is available. Kahneman is warning us to be careful with such information in our swaying judgment. It is what he calls the availability syndrome. Making judgments on how likely an event will happen based on how easy it is to think of an example. Availability doesn't equate to truth, he cautioned. Coming to the mind, he wrote that we think with two systems, system 1 and system 2. System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional. System 2, on the other hand, is slower, analytical, deliberative, and logical. Kahneman exposes the extraordinary capabilities—and also the faults and biases—of fast thinking, and reveals the pervasive influence of intuitive impressions on our thoughts and behaviour. Kahneman also shows that we tend to place more value on what we currently own more than it’s real economic value. He called it the “endowment effect”. With the endowment effect, our economic decisions are made through the lens of opportunity costs. The other key concept extensively discussed in the book is “Loss Aversion” or status quo bias. That is, we work harder not to lose something than we will gain something. Losing something pains twice than the joy of winning. All-in-all, this book is a must-read for everyone. I cannot recommend it highly enough. All-in-all, this book is a must-read for everyone. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

This is by far the best book I've ever read. He describes that how most of our choices in normal life are governed by subconscious because system 2 is lazy and he gave many examples around it.Reversion to the mean was a tremendous mind-opener. As also was choice making section where he describes the peak-end vs time biases where we tend to say that this guys life was successful because he reached to such a success height and his end was happy rather than integrating happiness vs time which would sort of be a better measure for success. It was ironic that after mentioning so many biases, he found the question of predicting the future very defined by the asset pricing. But, he more than made by the rest of the content.A JEWEL!

In one sentence: a book about when our intuitions are wrong. And it's A-MA-ZING.The "fast" and "slow" in the title are references to what has been traditionally (and incorrectly) called "Right hemisphere" and "Left hemisphere" (also R-mode and L-mode). Kahneman calls them System 1 (the intuitive) and System 2 (the (seemingly) rational) and goes into interesting details about how they interact. He writes about intuitive judgements and how we get them wrong; about probability and how we get it wrong; about cost/benefit analysis and how we get it wrong; about our memory of the past and how we get it wrong.The ideas are not new, but they are definitely mind-blowing if you haven't encountered them before. They are presented with great examples. All of this is the result of rigorous research and not hand-waving – there is an impressive list of references in the back (I followed a few and was satisfied).If you want to know more about how your brain makes your decision and what are the most common pitfalls, this book is for you.

I enjoyed this book more than any new book that I've read in at least a decade. Probably in two decades.Thinking, Fast and Slow talks about two distinct modes of thinking - the "fast" intuitive thinking that dominates much of what we do and the slow, effort-demanding, conceptual thinking that we can bring to bear. It does this in amazing, and I suspect original, detail.Superficially, the book is about cognitive biases, various forms of error and a psychological, rather than philosophical, look at volition. More deeply, it really gives an impression of what focus means and patterns of applying it so well that I believe that for most people it will be "the best book about" the half dozen or so things that he or she really cares about. It so startlingly illuminates some basic facts about thinking that you'll inevitably apply it to the things that you care about and understand them better because you understand the actors better.Everyone should read this book.2016: I picked as much up from the second reading as the first. There is just so much there.

There is so much to be said about this book that I hardly feel up to the task of saying it. This book was suggested and I therefore grabbed it from the library when I saw it available. It's kind of amazing that he's couched a book on decision making using statistics in the context of fast and slow thinking. The more into statistics you are the easier this book will be to absorb.System 1 - Fast - This might be what one refers to you nearly unconscious judgements. This will attempt to process, answer, and understand any question choice or otherwise as quickly as possible. System 2 - Slow - This requires more cognitive horse power. It must be activated on purpose. You get tired if you over use this. Then there is this concept of "Flow"P. 41 "Riding a motorcycle at 150 miles an hour and playing a competitive game of chess are certainly effortful. IN a state of flow, howevere, maintainig focused attention on these absorbing activities requires no exertion of self-control, thereby freeing resources to be directed to the task at ahand. The mind is a pattern maker and will make things that are not related related. This was discovered by Hume. in 1945 (p. 76). He gives the example that if you animate lights such that one is still and the other is moving, but when the still one is touched by the moving the two switch and the still one continues in the same path, then the mind will attribute cause to the moving light. The point is you know that the lights are animated and the real cause is the animator. You're mind however, will represent that light one caused light 2 to move. Fascinating.Chapter 9 drives home the point that it is uncomfortable to be stumped and need to use System 2. It more or less goes through all the cognitive biases we have just so we don't have eto use System 2.I like this end point of Chapter 16. He attempts to drive home how hard headed most humans are. Even if we know the statistical answer we will not truly integrate that into decisions made. P. 174. People who are taught surprising statistical facts about human behavior may be impressed to the point of telling their friends what they have heard, but this does not mean that their world has actually changed. The chapter gives the example of how someone having a stroke does not elicit a bunch of people willing to help, because in actuality most will not get involved if they think someone else might take care of it. I like it because if you consider such biases in the discrimination issues of today, it really points out something fascinating. I'll try to think more on that when i have time. Chapter 22 is interesting in that he attempts to address the issue of expert intuition. In some ways this speaks directly to the book Blink. It would be interesting to have them face off. First, we define expert as someone who has literally seen every variation and understands it, a la master chess player. They are not intuiting. They are exercising the skill. But then then the question comes in whether they know what they don't know. Hard to say. But I do like the idea that expert is a host of skills that are complementary together. p.241 - "Expertise is not a single skill; it is a collection of skills, and the same professional may be highly expert in some of the tasks in her domain while remaining a novice in others." The next few chapters speak to risk and the biases of optimism and the like. Very cool stuff. (Emotional, cognitive, and social factors that bias risk).The ultimate conclusion is that we should attempt to fight errors of System 1. How...P. 417 - "recognize the signs that you are in a cognitive minefield, slow down, and ask for reinforcement from System 2."I also wonder if women and minorities are socialized in the work place to be better at this. Not the point of this guy's book though, but fascinating nonetheless.Point of view is everything in this book. He goes through more detail about each of the biases illustrated in the field of decision making. It's a worthwhile read. Context is everything. In this book, the idea of regression is that it is correct, but misinterpretted (a flawed understanding of regression to the mean). I speak specifically about Appendix A, p. 424. He's right. Inference is often a problem. But I typically use the same think to describe the idea that the data is misunderstood, so inference is always wrong. What you see is all there is.Kahneman talks about the forty years he has spent studying how humans make decisions, and the two main ways we make decisions—system 1 (intuition) and system 2 (slow, methodical)—and how we are easily deceived in any number of ways.While this was fascinating look at decision-making, this nearly 500-page tome boils down to one (well, two, if you set aside the oft-repeated mantra at the top of this review) take-away: if you are offered to participate in a psychological study, always decline.Perhaps this wasn't the take-away Kahneman intended, but it was certainly what I got from this, along with the thought that this could have benefited with a 200-page trim because there was a lot of material that felt repeated or over-explained.More seriously, I can see why this had been on the Commandant's Reading List for the past number of years, because it offers ways to think through decisions and avoiding making logical fallacies that ultimately will end in disaster or severe misunderstanding (oh how many majors I wish had actually read this before asking me to do stupid shit).Both gut instinct and slower thinking are discussed, along with their pros, cons, how these two systems can be tricked/influenced, and how to beat the system (basically, always double-check your work if you had time). Also: when it comes to many luck-based scenarios, the "experts" are often only slightly more efficient at guessing than the average layperson.It definitely left some interesting food for thought.

In the highly anticipated Thinking, Fast and Slow, Kahneman takes us on a groundbreaking tour of the mind and explains the two systems that drive the way we think. System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional; System 2 is slower, more deliberative, and more logical. Kahneman exposes the extraordinary capabilities—and also the faults and biases—of fast thinking, and reveals the pervasive influence of intuitive impressions on our thoughts and behavior. The impact of loss aversion and overconfidence on corporate strategies, the difficulties of predicting what will make us happy in the future, the challenges of properly framing risks at work and at home, the profound effect of cognitive biases on everything from playing the stock market to planning the next vacation—each of these can be understood only by knowing how the two systems work together to shape our judgments and decisions.Engaging the reader in a lively conversation about how we think, Kahneman reveals where we can and cannot trust our intuitions and how we can tap into the benefits of slow thinking. He offers practical and enlightening insights into how choices are made in both our business and our personal lives—and how we can use different techniques to guard against the mental glitches that often get us into trouble. Thinking, Fast and Slow will transform the way you think about thinking.

Having heard about this book for several years I was quite excited to finally start it. However, found myself quickly bored. Not to say that the book is bad or uninteresting but rather the majority of the concepts in the book are things I've learned in business/psychology classes. That being said, this book is a nice tidy summary of a lot of these ideas (how bias work, how humans are bad at stats, how our thinking can be influenced).I did go ahead and read the whole book in search of the nuggets of new info and here are some of the things I found and really liked:* Willpower is like a muscle that you build up. When you're mentally tired it's much easier to give in. And people who are cognitively busy are more likely to make selfish choices.* Money primes individualism* Being exposed to phrases/names a lot leads us to believe them* The font size/color influence how much we believe text* It's hard for us to accept that a lot of life is random (as opposed to skill)* Regression to the mean - a really powerful concept of how people who do above their average will likely regress to their average next time around. People who are below their average will likely do better next time around.* Narrative fallacy - We love stories and tend to believe them as we draw causal inferences* People will pay a premium to transfer risk to the rich (insurance policies)It should be noted, that this whole book was about the author's experiments and not all of them have successfully been reproduced. The Undoing Project is a book I have yet to read that rebutts a lot of the ideas put forth in this book.

This was a really interesting book. Thinking Fast and Slow is the culmination of years of Daniel Kahneman’s research into the nature of human decision making, how our minds process the world around us, and basically how people think. From the very start the reader must realize how difficult of a subject this is to explore and understand, let alone explain. Simply by being human, any researcher working on this has to keep in mind that he is prey to the very biases he is working to uncover.This book was organized and written very well. Kahneman divides the human mind into two systems from the very beginning, giving these systems traits and tendencies to help us relate to them in ourselves. System 1 is the fast and intuitive thinking, or (if I may generalize here) our subconscious thoughts; our automatic reactions, feelings and impressions. System 2 is our rational system; the one that is often more accurate, but takes up much more energy to use. Most of us can see those two “systems” within ourselves, and that makes the book easy to follow. He often brings up points that seem arbitrary only to have them neatly tied together to create a larger concept a chapter or two later.I feel like this book was created for those who tend to be of a less scientific mind. He uses examples of experiments very often in the book that seem on the surface to prove his point, but I often wondered about the details of the experiments, which were never included. Now don’t get me wrong; I know nothing about Kahneman’s career and have no reason to think he does not do his research as scientifically as possible; that information just isn’t included in the book. This is an overall explanation of what his research has led him to conclude; if you’re looking for details and numbers and results so you can reach your own conclusion, you won’t find it here. For example:He wrote about an experiment where subjects heard various groups of words, then had to walk down a hallway to another room to do the second part of the experiment. The actual experiment was how long it took them to walk down the hall. Some people were given words that related to older people, disabilities, and generally being slow while other people were given words that related to young people, fitness, and generally being fast. People who were given the “slow words” took a significantly longer amount of time to walk the distance of the hall than those given the “fast words.” That’s really all he tells the reader because that is all he needs to make his point. And reading that, it is very easy to jump to the conclusion “wow, just hearing words can change our actions” because it’s interesting. He doesn’t answer questions like: Could the words have evoked different themes in different people’s minds? Was a background of the subjects taken to determine their general mood? Were the fast words speeding people up or the slow words slowing people down? How do you know this doesn’t only work with certain themes? Etc.My point is, take Thinking Fast and Slow with a grain of salt. The book is fun to read in the way that personality tests are fun; it’s always neat to learn more about ourselves, and it fulfills that somewhat narcissistic need in the reader. But that’s system 1 thinking; if you go into this wanting proof, you won’t get it. This is a subject very difficult to study objectively, and while I’m sure he did the job as well as possible, you can’t know that by reading his book because he does not give details, he gives his conclusions. And who can blame him? You don’t sell a book by filling it with numbers, you sell it by making it easy to understand – and when you get into such cutting edge research, there just isn’t a way to make it widely accessible and include all the nitty gritty details.I do believe this book is a very important stepping stone. Kahneman’s research is just one step toward understanding the human mind. I think many of the experiments he talks about are not enough to draw conclusions, although he does the best that he can. Scientists will continue the same path of research he has taken for centuries to come, and his ideas will be expanded on, accepted or thrown out as we learn more. This isn’t absolute truth. But if you are interested in where we stand on understanding the human mind and what theories are out there, then this book will be invaluable to you.I do not in any way think reading it is a waste of time since the ideas will most certainly change. Throughout the book he points out many of the common illusions that people fall prey to because of certain biases in our minds, and even if he doesn’t have the processes behind them exactly right (who can really know if he does or not?), that doesn’t mean the illusions aren’t real. Everyone can benefit from reading this book simply by being made aware of these pitfalls and therefore being able to avoid them in the future.So, what do I think? He went a little light on the explanations, and I wish he had provided more of the scientific details about his work. However, I understand that the book is already lengthy and so he may not have had much choice. I do absolutely recommend this book for any non-fiction readers interested in psychology or in improving their own thought processes.

Why I started reading it: This is one those books that you can see on the shelves of youtubers, in the posts of bookstagramers and the ‘to read’ lists of most your friends.What I liked about it: The idea of explaining in rather scientific terms why we are not as rational as we think. To summarize:1. Our brain has 2 systems: fast intuitive and slow analytical. 2. Our brain wants to take the path of least resistance, which called Cognitive Ease.3. When faced with a difficult question, we answer a cognitively easier one. As a marketer we need to remember about this while runing surveys. 4. 'What you see is all there is' . From marketers perspective this is to justify things like branding or awareness campaigns.5. Our opinion can be changed depending on how the question/statement was. For example, which one do you think will sell better? 90% fat-free VS 10% fat?6. When judging likelihood we over value what 'Feels' right and undervalue statistics. 7. We hate the idea of 'wasting ' what we have already put in.

Overall I really enjoyed this book. Kahneman is an engaging writer and brings in a wealth of information to construct a compelling narrative. I'd been aware of a lot of this literature and the overall framework beforehand, but I still learned a lot in terms of specifics and got a much better sense of the details of the system 1/system 2 model and how broadly applicable it is. If you want a glimpse of what kind of understanding psychology can offer of how we reason and evaluate, I definitely recommend this one.I had some minor nits throughout and disagreed with a few of his interpretations, but the significant detractor was the framing Kahneman chose for the book. He made some choices seemingly to promote his goal of influencing water cooler conversation (which by itself seemed strange to me) that I think weakened chances for understanding. The biggest one was the discussion of the separate categories of thought processes as separate systems with their own agency and personalities. Kahneman acknowledges this as a fiction explicitly, but that didn't seem to mitigate the confusion that I think might result. I do think there's a true and useful categorization underneath the system 1/system 2 distinction, but treating them as completely distinct and partially at odds obfuscates the deeply intertwined and inseparable nature of the processes. One particular recurrent issue that resulted from this was identifying system 2 with the self and then concluding (at several different points) things along the lines of "you don't really know/decide/etc. most things, that's sneaky old System 1". And ascribing judgmental personality traits to the systems (e.g. "system 2 is lazy" instead of "effortful thinking is costly") may help the reader from an intuitive impression of them, but with a strong bias toward oversimplification and negative evaluation.More minorly, Kahneman also usually leaves out details like how strong the effects noted are, what proportion of the subjects were affected, etc. seemingly out of a desire to craft a coherent picture that applies wholly to the reader. One of the times where he does include some of this information this gets particularly ridiculous: In one paragraph on page 171 he mentions that "only four of the fifteen participants [in the "helping experiment"] responded immediately to the appeal for help," and in the next says "even normal, decent people do not rush to help when they expect others to take on the unpleasantness of dealing with a seizure. And that means you, too.". 4/15 is pretty bad given the issue at hand, but if that generalizes it emphatically doesn't mean "you" for more than 1 in 4 of the readers! Many of the errors he mentioned I could easily identify in myself, some of them I have evidence for thinking they don't apply as strongly as he claims (e.g. actually having been in a few diffusion of responsibility type scenarios and taking action), and for the rest I simply have no way to judge likelihood without diving into the references. I think adding in these details would have gone a long way to forming a more accurate understanding in the reader, but I have an uncharitable suspicion that it would also have significantly weakened some of the cases he was making.All that being said, I really did enjoy this book and by the end couldn't put it down. Kahneman clearly knows his stuff and I'm much better informed having read it. I've already taken steps to try to incorporate some of the lessons into my thinking and decision making, and definitely plan to seek out more in this domain.

I am familiar with Daniel Kahneman's work through many of his essays and articles in various magazines in the past. I had always found them thought-provoking, interesting and challenging established notions. That is why I was excited to read this book on Behavioral psychology by him. However, this book lived up to my expectations only partially. One reason is that the author's contention that 'our intuitive preferences are more influential than rational choice' gets well established fairly early in the book through the many experiments that he describes. Consequently, I felt a sense of repetition in the latter half of the book and gradually felt that the book lost steam completely towards the closing sections.To put it simply, the book says that there are two systems which drive the way we think and make choices. The author calls them System 1 and System 2. System 1 is intuitive, quick and influenced by emotion. System 2 is slower, rational, logical and reflective. The author's research says that System 1 is more influential than what our experience tells us and it is the subliminal determinant of the many choices and judgments that we make. This is contrary to our general belief that we are very rational in our decision-making. The many example experiments that the book outlines show us that we must really be a lot more watchful in the assurance with which we trust our decisions as rooted in rationality. To me, this is the biggest lesson from the book.A few other points of interest from the book are:1. Luck plays a large role in every story of success. The author illustrates it with the telling contemporary example of the founders of Google willing to sell their company for less than $1 million but the buyer thought that the price was too high!2. High intelligence does not make people immune to biases3. Rationality should be distinguished from intelligence.4. While talking about the consequences of Priming, the author points to a conclusion that may be an indictment of capitalist society. He says that living in a culture that surrounds us with constant reminders of money may shape our behavior and attitudes in ways that we do not know about and of which we may not be proud.5. On the subject of Intuition vs Formulas, the author quotes a memorable formula of researcher Robyn Dawes:Marital Stability = frequency of lovemaking - frequency of quarrels!6. In the final section of the book, titled 'Two Selves', the author dabbles into the question of human happiness. Two statements caught my attention.a. The easiest way to increase happiness is to control your use of time. Can you find more time to do the things you enjoy doing?b. There is low correlation between individuals' circumstances and their satisfaction with life. The reason is that both experienced happiness and life satisfaction are largely determined by the genetics of temperament.In this context, I wondered whether the author is aware of Friedrich Nietzsche's contention that animals are happy because they lack a capacity for past memories. Perhaps the author's term 'genetics of temperament' include a capacity to forget the past and move on with life.I found it educational and interesting in parts but somewhat disappointing overall, given my initial expectations from the author.

In 1979, Kahneman with his longtime collaborator, Late Amos Tversky published their groundbreaking academic paper, “Prospect Theory” (which was further updated in 1992). It was a buzz in the academic world. Kahneman who later went on to receive Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 2002 is the first psychologist to earn the prize in that category. Kahneman sequenced into a book hundreds of research papers spanning over 30 years on decision making he wrote with his intellectual friend and collaborator, Tversky. Thinking Fast and Slow is his seminal work on the topic of decision making and cognitive bias.Thinking Fast and Slow is a dense, technical but rewarding read. The book exhaustively discussed biases and fallacies people are prone to make. He talks about the halo effect, affection bias, and confirmation biases. The crux of the book is on cognitive biases, yeah.Humans are said to be “rational beings.” That we are capable of making rational and logical choices. But Kahneman argues it is not always so. “Humans beings,” he insists, “are prone to make illogical choices. We rely so much on statistics, numbers, or information. We are quick at even saying “numbers don’t lie.’ Because we think along those lines, when we are fed with information about a particular issue, we start to feel that it is true or even concludes it has a higher likelihood of reoccurrence. We also make an intuitive judgment based on the information that is available. Kahneman is warning us to be careful with such information in our swaying judgment. It is what he calls the availability syndrome. Making judgments on how likely an event will happen based on how easy it is to think of an example. Availability doesn't equate to truth, he cautioned. Coming to the mind, he wrote that we think with two systems, system 1 and system 2. System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional. System 2, on the other hand, is slower, analytical, deliberative, and logical. Kahneman exposes the extraordinary capabilities—and also the faults and biases—of fast thinking, and reveals the pervasive influence of intuitive impressions on our thoughts and behaviour. Kahneman also shows that we tend to place more value on what we currently own more than it’s real economic value. He called it the “endowment effect”. With the endowment effect, our economic decisions are made through the lens of opportunity costs. The other key concept extensively discussed in the book is “Loss Aversion” or status quo bias. That is, we work harder not to lose something than we will gain something. Losing something pains twice than the joy of winning. All-in-all, this book is a must-read for everyone. I cannot recommend it highly enough. All-in-all, this book is a must-read for everyone. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

This is by far the best book I've ever read. I cannot emphasize more on reading this book before all the others!Over small chapters spread over the entire book, nobel prize winner Kahneman goes on to describe initially how system 1 (subconscious) and your system 2 (conscious) work. He describes that how most of our choices in normal life are governed by subconscious because system 2 is lazy and he gave many examples around it.Reversion to the mean was a tremendous mind-opener. As also was choice making section where he describes the peak-end vs time biases where we tend to say that this guys life was successful because he reached to such a success height and his end was happy rather than integrating happiness vs time which would sort of be a better measure for success. This happens because our long term memory tends to remember the peak and end more than overall time experience because they're the strong memory points.One part which I found was wrong was Kahneman's belief in efficient market theory. It was ironic that after mentioning so many biases, he found the question of predicting the future very defined by the asset pricing. But, he more than made by the rest of the content.A JEWEL!

In one sentence: a book about when our intuitions are wrong. And it's A-MA-ZING.The "fast" and "slow" in the title are references to what has been traditionally (and incorrectly) called "Right hemisphere" and "Left hemisphere" (also R-mode and L-mode). Kahneman calls them System 1 (the intuitive) and System 2 (the (seemingly) rational) and goes into interesting details about how they interact. He writes about intuitive judgements and how we get them wrong; about probability and how we get it wrong; about cost/benefit analysis and how we get it wrong; about our memory of the past and how we get it wrong.The ideas are not new, but they are definitely mind-blowing if you haven't encountered them before. They are presented with great examples. All of this is the result of rigorous research and not hand-waving – there is an impressive list of references in the back (I followed a few and was satisfied).If you want to know more about how your brain makes your decision and what are the most common pitfalls, this book is for you.

I enjoyed this book more than any new book that I've read in at least a decade. Probably in two decades.Thinking, Fast and Slow talks about two distinct modes of thinking - the "fast" intuitive thinking that dominates much of what we do and the slow, effort-demanding, conceptual thinking that we can bring to bear. It does this in amazing, and I suspect original, detail.Superficially, the book is about cognitive biases, various forms of error and a psychological, rather than philosophical, look at volition. More deeply, it really gives an impression of what focus means and patterns of applying it so well that I believe that for most people it will be "the best book about" the half dozen or so things that he or she really cares about. It so startlingly illuminates some basic facts about thinking that you'll inevitably apply it to the things that you care about and understand them better because you understand the actors better.Everyone should read this book.2016: I picked as much up from the second reading as the first. There is just so much there.

There is so much to be said about this book that I hardly feel up to the task of saying it. This book was suggested and I therefore grabbed it from the library when I saw it available. It's kind of amazing that he's couched a book on decision making using statistics in the context of fast and slow thinking. The more into statistics you are the easier this book will be to absorb.System 1 - Fast - This might be what one refers to you nearly unconscious judgements. This will attempt to process, answer, and understand any question choice or otherwise as quickly as possible. System 2 - Slow - This requires more cognitive horse power. It must be activated on purpose. You get tired if you over use this. Then there is this concept of "Flow"P. 41 "Riding a motorcycle at 150 miles an hour and playing a competitive game of chess are certainly effortful. IN a state of flow, howevere, maintainig focused attention on these absorbing activities requires no exertion of self-control, thereby freeing resources to be directed to the task at ahand. The mind is a pattern maker and will make things that are not related related. This was discovered by Hume. in 1945 (p. 76). He gives the example that if you animate lights such that one is still and the other is moving, but when the still one is touched by the moving the two switch and the still one continues in the same path, then the mind will attribute cause to the moving light. The point is you know that the lights are animated and the real cause is the animator. You're mind however, will represent that light one caused light 2 to move. Fascinating.Chapter 9 drives home the point that it is uncomfortable to be stumped and need to use System 2. It more or less goes through all the cognitive biases we have just so we don't have eto use System 2.I like this end point of Chapter 16. He attempts to drive home how hard headed most humans are. Even if we know the statistical answer we will not truly integrate that into decisions made. P. 174. People who are taught surprising statistical facts about human behavior may be impressed to the point of telling their friends what they have heard, but this does not mean that their world has actually changed. The chapter gives the example of how someone having a stroke does not elicit a bunch of people willing to help, because in actuality most will not get involved if they think someone else might take care of it. I like it because if you consider such biases in the discrimination issues of today, it really points out something fascinating. I'll try to think more on that when i have time. Chapter 22 is interesting in that he attempts to address the issue of expert intuition. In some ways this speaks directly to the book Blink. It would be interesting to have them face off. First, we define expert as someone who has literally seen every variation and understands it, a la master chess player. They are not intuiting. They are exercising the skill. But then then the question comes in whether they know what they don't know. Hard to say. But I do like the idea that expert is a host of skills that are complementary together. p.241 - "Expertise is not a single skill; it is a collection of skills, and the same professional may be highly expert in some of the tasks in her domain while remaining a novice in others." The next few chapters speak to risk and the biases of optimism and the like. Very cool stuff. (Emotional, cognitive, and social factors that bias risk).The ultimate conclusion is that we should attempt to fight errors of System 1. How...P. 417 - "recognize the signs that you are in a cognitive minefield, slow down, and ask for reinforcement from System 2."I also wonder if women and minorities are socialized in the work place to be better at this. Not the point of this guy's book though, but fascinating nonetheless.Point of view is everything in this book. He goes through more detail about each of the biases illustrated in the field of decision making. It's a worthwhile read. Context is everything. In this book, the idea of regression is that it is correct, but misinterpretted (a flawed understanding of regression to the mean). I speak specifically about Appendix A, p. 424. He's right. Inference is often a problem. But I typically use the same think to describe the idea that the data is misunderstood, so inference is always wrong. Also, I likely am more intrigued by the idea that average isn't a real thing. I think Kanneman is game on this, but it's outside the scope of the book.Learned a lot, not the least of which, is how to present quite technical stats in a way that might make you read about it.

This is not a book. It's a Noble Prize winner giving away all his secrets in a single serving.Why you must get it:- This is not a 1 book. It's 4-5 books of incredible wisdom packed together.- The crux of the book revolves around how humans think and make decisions. There are economic, psychology & real-life examples all through. How much does the ball cost?"- How friendly Stock Symbols help a Company- Moses Illusion "How many animals of each kind did Moses take into the ark?” - Anchoring effects explain why, for example, arbitrary rationing is an effective marketing ploy - the case of the limited sales of Campbell soup.- “The emotional tail wags the rational dog.”- “Alar scare” of 1989 illustrates a basic limitation in the ability of our mind to deal with small risks: we either ignore them altogether or give them far too much weight—nothing in between.- “He won’t go far as an academic; too many tattoos.” (mental roadblocks)- The case of the broken plates and how that affected price perception- The INCREDIBLE section on the "regression to the mean" How praise and rebuke have no correlation to performance. What you see is all there is.Kahneman talks about the forty years he has spent studying how humans make decisions, and the two main ways we make decisions—system 1 (intuition) and system 2 (slow, methodical)—and how we are easily deceived in any number of ways.While this was fascinating look at decision-making, this nearly 500-page tome boils down to one (well, two, if you set aside the oft-repeated mantra at the top of this review) take-away: if you are offered to participate in a psychological study, always decline.Perhaps this wasn't the take-away Kahneman intended, but it was certainly what I got from this, along with the thought that this could have benefited with a 200-page trim because there was a lot of material that felt repeated or over-explained.More seriously, I can see why this had been on the Commandant's Reading List for the past number of years, because it offers ways to think through decisions and avoiding making logical fallacies that ultimately will end in disaster or severe misunderstanding (oh how many majors I wish had actually read this before asking me to do stupid shit).Both gut instinct and slower thinking are discussed, along with their pros, cons, how these two systems can be tricked/influenced, and how to beat the system (basically, always double-check your work if you had time). Also: when it comes to many luck-based scenarios, the "experts" are often only slightly more efficient at guessing than the average layperson.It definitely left some interesting food for thought.

In the highly anticipated Thinking, Fast and Slow, Kahneman takes us on a groundbreaking tour of the mind and explains the two systems that drive the way we think. System 1 is fast, intuitive, and emotional; System 2 is slower, more deliberative, and more logical. Kahneman exposes the extraordinary capabilities—and also the faults and biases—of fast thinking, and reveals the pervasive influence of intuitive impressions on our thoughts and behavior. The impact of loss aversion and overconfidence on corporate strategies, the difficulties of predicting what will make us happy in the future, the challenges of properly framing risks at work and at home, the profound effect of cognitive biases on everything from playing the stock market to planning the next vacation—each of these can be understood only by knowing how the two systems work together to shape our judgments and decisions.Engaging the reader in a lively conversation about how we think, Kahneman reveals where we can and cannot trust our intuitions and how we can tap into the benefits of slow thinking. He offers practical and enlightening insights into how choices are made in both our business and our personal lives—and how we can use different techniques to guard against the mental glitches that often get us into trouble. Thinking, Fast and Slow will transform the way you think about thinking.

Thinking, Fast and Slow (2011) by Daniel Kahneman is a fascinating insight into how our brains work, and how our judgement can easily be influenced by a range of surprising factors. It's hard to imagine there's anyone who wouldn't benefit from understanding the insights of Nobel Prize winning Daniel Kahneman.4/5Thinking, Fast and Slow (2011) by Daniel Kahneman

Having heard about this book for several years I was quite excited to finally start it. However, found myself quickly bored. Not to say that the book is bad or uninteresting but rather the majority of the concepts in the book are things I've learned in business/psychology classes. That being said, this book is a nice tidy summary of a lot of these ideas (how bias work, how humans are bad at stats, how our thinking can be influenced).I did go ahead and read the whole book in search of the nuggets of new info and here are some of the things I found and really liked:* Willpower is like a muscle that you build up. When you're mentally tired it's much easier to give in. And people who are cognitively busy are more likely to make selfish choices.* Money primes individualism* Being exposed to phrases/names a lot leads us to believe them* The font size/color influence how much we believe text* It's hard for us to accept that a lot of life is random (as opposed to skill)* Regression to the mean - a really powerful concept of how people who do above their average will likely regress to their average next time around. People who are below their average will likely do better next time around.* Narrative fallacy - We love stories and tend to believe them as we draw causal inferences* People will pay a premium to transfer risk to the rich (insurance policies)It should be noted, that this whole book was about the author's experiments and not all of them have successfully been reproduced. The Undoing Project is a book I have yet to read that rebutts a lot of the ideas put forth in this book.

This was a really interesting book. Thinking Fast and Slow is the culmination of years of Daniel Kahneman’s research into the nature of human decision making, how our minds process the world around us, and basically how people think. From the very start the reader must realize how difficult of a subject this is to explore and understand, let alone explain. Simply by being human, any researcher working on this has to keep in mind that he is prey to the very biases he is working to uncover.This book was organized and written very well. Kahneman divides the human mind into two systems from the very beginning, giving these systems traits and tendencies to help us relate to them in ourselves. System 1 is the fast and intuitive thinking, or (if I may generalize here) our subconscious thoughts; our automatic reactions, feelings and impressions. System 2 is our rational system; the one that is often more accurate, but takes up much more energy to use. Most of us can see those two “systems” within ourselves, and that makes the book easy to follow. He often brings up points that seem arbitrary only to have them neatly tied together to create a larger concept a chapter or two later.I feel like this book was created for those who tend to be of a less scientific mind. He uses examples of experiments very often in the book that seem on the surface to prove his point, but I often wondered about the details of the experiments, which were never included. Now don’t get me wrong; I know nothing about Kahneman’s career and have no reason to think he does not do his research as scientifically as possible; that information just isn’t included in the book. This is an overall explanation of what his research has led him to conclude; if you’re looking for details and numbers and results so you can reach your own conclusion, you won’t find it here. For example:He wrote about an experiment where subjects heard various groups of words, then had to walk down a hallway to another room to do the second part of the experiment. The actual experiment was how long it took them to walk down the hall. Some people were given words that related to older people, disabilities, and generally being slow while other people were given words that related to young people, fitness, and generally being fast. People who were given the “slow words” took a significantly longer amount of time to walk the distance of the hall than those given the “fast words.” That’s really all he tells the reader because that is all he needs to make his point. And reading that, it is very easy to jump to the conclusion “wow, just hearing words can change our actions” because it’s interesting. He doesn’t answer questions like: Could the words have evoked different themes in different people’s minds? Was a background of the subjects taken to determine their general mood? Were the fast words speeding people up or the slow words slowing people down? How do you know this doesn’t only work with certain themes? Etc.My point is, take Thinking Fast and Slow with a grain of salt. The book is fun to read in the way that personality tests are fun; it’s always neat to learn more about ourselves, and it fulfills that somewhat narcissistic need in the reader. But that’s system 1 thinking; if you go into this wanting proof, you won’t get it. This is a subject very difficult to study objectively, and while I’m sure he did the job as well as possible, you can’t know that by reading his book because he does not give details, he gives his conclusions. And who can blame him? You don’t sell a book by filling it with numbers, you sell it by making it easy to understand – and when you get into such cutting edge research, there just isn’t a way to make it widely accessible and include all the nitty gritty details.I do believe this book is a very important stepping stone. Kahneman’s research is just one step toward understanding the human mind. I think many of the experiments he talks about are not enough to draw conclusions, although he does the best that he can. Scientists will continue the same path of research he has taken for centuries to come, and his ideas will be expanded on, accepted or thrown out as we learn more. This isn’t absolute truth. But if you are interested in where we stand on understanding the human mind and what theories are out there, then this book will be invaluable to you.I do not in any way think reading it is a waste of time since the ideas will most certainly change. Throughout the book he points out many of the common illusions that people fall prey to because of certain biases in our minds, and even if he doesn’t have the processes behind them exactly right (who can really know if he does or not?), that doesn’t mean the illusions aren’t real. Everyone can benefit from reading this book simply by being made aware of these pitfalls and therefore being able to avoid them in the future.So, what do I think? He went a little light on the explanations, and I wish he had provided more of the scientific details about his work. However, I understand that the book is already lengthy and so he may not have had much choice. I do absolutely recommend this book for any non-fiction readers interested in psychology or in improving their own thought processes.

To summarize:1. Our brain has 2 systems: fast intuitive and slow analytical. 2. Our brain wants to take the path of least resistance, which called Cognitive Ease.3. When faced with a difficult question, we answer a cognitively easier one. As a marketer we need to remember about this while runing surveys. 4. 'What you see is all there is' .
